Author: Alright#0419
Content: so if people start setting up stratums for these chains and don't realize they can't use p2p notify, we'll have problems

Author: Alright#0419
Content: it wasn't in a second

Author: Alright#0419
Content: it's because blocktemplate for knomp is only updated when a block comes in

Author: Alright#0419
Content: then it uses the "curtime" value for nTime

Author: Alright#0419
Content: which will always be the second after the block came in

Author: Alright#0419
Content: well it updates every 55 seconds

Author: Alright#0419
Content: so if it finds a block within those 55 seconds, it will always be +1 second

Author: Alright#0419
Content: and make diff go up

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: not optimal behavior for mining apow chains

Author: Alright#0419
Content:
ok I think this can *kind of* be used to make money... well at least prevent others from making money while you switch off to something else

Let's say you have a switching setup, you're mining ZAWY24 and decide you want to switch to something else for a bit, you raise the diff to ridiculous levels, leave, mine something else then come back once diff normalizes?

Author: Alright#0419
Content: is basically the same as normal switching, but instead of gaining more blocks, you just make everyone else get less

Author: Alright#0419
Content: idk, still formulating ideas, I just find it strange that a miner can raise the diff(drastically) at will by changing nTime

Author: Alright#0419
Content:
curious how the cumulative pow thing is affected by this(thing that determines when or when not to reorg to another chain)

like can I just keep mining at these massive diffs and the network not reorg to the honest chain(longer but less pow) because of it?

Author: Alright#0419
Content:
ok let's say chain is at very high diff because of time stamp thing I just mentioned, it's stuck at block 100

honest miners wait until diff comes down and produce block 101 with low diff, then block 102, 103, 104, 105

I ignore their 101-105 and produce my own 101 at block 100+1 second and very high diff

if my 101 chain has >pow than their 105 chain, will the network jump back to my 101?

Author: Alright#0419
Content: then have to wait for diff to come down again

Author: zawy#5864
Content: The way to attack is to pester the public chain into higher average difficulties that reduces average rewards for mining.  Perhaps someone with 25% HR could assign a +1 stamp whenever he found a block..I'm not sure this can actually raise avg difficulty for others.....but if it can, and if it's like other chains where 70% of miners leave if difficulty rises 30%, then he can simulatneously do 5 to 10 block private mines and submit those.....at much lower difficulty cost due to the public chain not having gained much work due to 70% leaving.  After he submits, the difficulty is a lot lower, so normally a lot of miners jump back on.  So he could only do it periodically

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but exp() sort of defeats this

Author: zawy#5864
Content: He would do it to try to be just below the level of exp() kicking in.  He only needs to make avg difficulty higher by say 30% to see a lot more than 30% of miners lose interest

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but even RST activating will start adjusting the diff to the actual hashrate

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: not sure you can boost the diff 30% consistently without triggering RST

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but in any case the coin emission is not increased, which is the bigger picture issue

Author: zawy#5864
Content: Yes, if my math and general idea is correct and the chain work uses the targetB, this is not supposed to be possible

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: all these thing slow down coin emission, which seems relatively benign

Author: zawy#5864
Content: private miners trying to boost the public chain difficulty when they start their private mine is something that happens.....it's just something to be aware of and to try to prove to yourself they can't benefit
